columns.text: In this exercise,  we are going to learn about put-call parity.

To start with, let's define put-call parity. 

A **put-call parity** is the correlation between a call and put option which is connected on the same underlying futures contract. This option contract has the same exercise price, expiration date, and asset.

The equation of put call parity is illustrated below: 

$$\text{S}+\text{P}=\text{X}(\text{E})^{\text{rt}}+\text{C}$$

Where: 

- S - Current price of the stock
- PV - Present value of strike price
- P - Put option
- C - Call option
- r - Risk-free rate
- t - Time

The sum of the stock price and put option is equal to the sum of the present value of the strike price and call option.

Here are the parameters to solve the requirement : 

|Given | | 
|--|--| 
|Call option (C)|$3.21 | 
|Exercise price of call option |$70 | 
|e | 2.71828| 
| Risk-free rate (r) |2.6% | 
|Time (t) |Quarterly or 1/4 or 0.25 | 
|Stock Price (S) |$67 |

Now, using the equation in Step 3, the price of the put option is solved below: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\$67+\textbf{P}&=[(70)(2.71828)^{-(0.026)(0.25)}]+\$3.21\\[10pt]
\$67+\textbf{P}&=[(70)(2.71828)^{-0.0065}]+\$3.21\\[10pt]
\$67+\textbf{P}&=[(70)(0.9935)]+\$3.21\\[10pt]
\$67+\textbf{P}&=\$69.55+\$3.21\\[10pt]
\$67+\textbf{P}&=\$72.76\\[10pt]
\textbf{P}&=\$72.76-\$67\\[10pt]
\textbf{P}&=\boxed{\$5.76}
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the price of the put option is $5.76.
